title: Maker's Schedule, Manager's Schedule (2009)
summary: Paul Graham's influential essay argues that people who make things (programmers, writers, designers) operate on a fundamentally different schedule than managers. Makers need large uninterrupted blocks of time (ideally half-days or full days) to do deep work, while managers work in hour-long appointment blocks. The central complaint: a single meeting can destroy a maker's entire afternoon by fragmenting it into pieces too small for meaningful work. The discussion thread explores practical implementations of this principle, with commenters sharing their experiences scheduling maker time, debating whether the theory is actionable in practice, and discussing enterprise dysfunction. Notable themes include memory allocation analogies, block scheduling strategies (dedicating specific days to maker time), the tension between maker and manager roles, and skepticism about whether better meetings could solve the real underlying problem.
what_happened: The concept became widely influential in tech culture and was adopted as a principle by many engineering organizations. However, the practical outcome has been mixed. Remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic (2020) initially seemed like it could enable maker schedules—work-from-home removed commute and provided more control over one's time. Yet the opposite occurred: meeting frequency increased by 69.7% post-2020, and the number of meetings has become a chronic problem in tech. Major companies like Dropbox institutionalized 'Hack Week' (dedicated uninterrupted time), and Google added 'Focus Time' features to Calendar. However, these remain aspirational: highly productive engineering teams achieve 70% maker time, but many organizations fall far short. Google's own '20% time' program, which embodied similar thinking, never reached more than 10% actual participation as quarterly pressures grew. The article's diagnosis was correct, but the industry's ability to implement the solution has remained limited. Remote work eliminated commuting time but replaced it with more asynchronous interruptions via Slack, email, and expanded meeting culture. The pandemic actually worsened the problem despite theoretical conditions being favorable for maker time.

most_prescient.reason: His heap fragmentation/memory allocation analogy for schedule fragmentation is remarkably prescient and has become the canonical technical explanation for the concept. His observation that fragmenting a developer's day creates an allocation problem not solvable by mere context-switching discipline has held up perfectly over 16 years. This analogy is still cited in contemporary discussions of focus time and deep work. He also correctly identified 'office hours' as the memory pool solution, which many companies (Dropbox, Google) later formally adopted.

most_wrong.reason: His lengthy critique argues that the Maker's Schedule theory is 'indulgent' and the real solution is 'better meetings' and more communication. He suggests that high-engagement developer-focused meetings (architectural discussions, code review, brainstorming) would solve the problem better than blocking meeting time. Reality has decisively proven him wrong: post-2020, meeting culture exploded despite remote work opportunities, developers became more protective of their time, and research shows the fundamental interruption problem (not just meeting quality) is the core issue. His faith that 'better meetings' could replace the need for uninterrupted blocks has been falsified by observed behavior.

notable_aspects: The thread includes creative scheduling hacks that later became industry standard: JoshTriplett and others describe blocking entire days/afternoons on calendars to force meetings into specific slots—this is now formalized as many companies' official policy. Interestingly, the comment by engi_nerd about his boss demanding he 'work more efficiently between interruptions' is darkly humorous and predicted exactly how many organizations would respond (blame the maker, not the schedule). The discussion presciently identifies Conway's Law as a core issue in enterprise software complexity. Mark Eijsermans mentions Dropbox's Wed/Thurs no-meeting policy, which actually materialized into formalized practices. The thread shows the early tech community understood the problem deeply but underestimated how difficult implementation would be at scale.

sharemywin.rationale: Simple validation that the concept makes sense, nothing wrong with his take. The observation about 'programmers block' being analogous to writer's block is a natural insight that holds up.

beat.rationale: Correctly identifies the essay's utility across many contexts (enterprise, startups) and that it helps even those skeptical of startup culture understand the underlying principle. His observation that enterprise workers often understand these constraints better than startup culture gives them credit for has proven accurate.

cpach.rationale: Asks a reasonable clarifying question about PG's enterprise skepticism. The answer validates that the issue is structural, not cultural bias.

famousactress.rationale: Excellent critique that pinpoints the real problem: misaligned incentives and broken feedback loops in enterprises, not just schedule fragmentation. This has only become more obviously true. Her skepticism of the 'problems are just harder at scale' argument has aged well.

munificent.rationale: The memory allocation analogy is so good it became canonical. His insight about how fragmentation creates unsolvable problems even with total available time is profound and has proven increasingly relevant as tools multiply.

jttam.rationale: Practical implementation observation about splitting weeks (1 manager day, 4 maker days) is sound and was later adopted by many organizations. The strategy has proven viable.

daniel_iversen.rationale: Simple but critical observation: Dropbox found that explicitly calendaring 'maker time' was respected by colleagues when organizational culture supported it. This became industry best practice.

engi_nerd.rationale: His anecdote about the manager demanding more efficiency between interruptions is a perfectly captured example of how the problem manifests in dysfunctional organizations. The outcome (leaving the job) is the rational response this predicts.

mark_eijsermans.rationale: Reports actual successful implementation at their company (Wed/Thu no-meetings) and identifies the tradeoff: harder to schedule, but higher quality meetings. This was prescient about what would become industry practice.

JoshTriplett.rationale: Describes effective calendar-blocking strategies (all-day Wed/Thu meetings as decoys to protect actual work time) that many later adopted. Identifies the timezone coordination tradeoff, which has become more relevant post-pandemic.

gklitt.rationale: The afternoon-blocking strategy and observation that 'most meetings don't have a specific required time' is validated by remote work experience. The caveat about org-wide coordination becoming necessary has proven prescient.

dmichulke.rationale: Personal optimization of maker time (morning deep work, afternoon meetings) is sound but somewhat idiosyncratic. The insight about thinking through problems at night is valid but not universally applicable.

mwsherman.rationale: The managerial perspective that 'being interrupted is the job' is true but incomplete. While managing interruptions gracefully is important, this doesn't negate the fundamental problem PG identified. Acceptable but somewhat defensive.

beachstartup.rationale: Points out the real tension: expecting people to do both manager and maker work simultaneously. This has only worsened—tech IC/manager hybrids have become more common, not less.

JacobAldridge.rationale: Connects maker schedule to broader behavioral economics (fast/slow pace preference). Interesting connection but somewhat tangential to the core issue.

ianbicking.rationale: Well-argued but fundamentally wrong prediction. Claims 'better meetings' are the solution and that meeting avoidance causes dysfunction. Post-2020 evidence shows the opposite: meeting explosion harmed productivity, and boundaries around meeting time improved it. His faith in communication solving the fragmentation problem has been disproven.

mpdehaan2.rationale: Balanced take that acknowledges both the importance of uninterrupted work AND the necessity of some meetings. The videogame 'charge up' metaphor is apt. Less prescient than others but not wrong.
